TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: uzai a qam katua gang ka sitsuayan.
ozai a qam katoa gang ka sicoayan.
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time there were an ant-eater and a crab.

S.FORM: a gang katsuin na qam a kikaludjeł.
a gang kacoin na qam a kikalodjelj.
S.TRANSL: The ant-eater took the crab to get loquats.

S.FORM: qau kiłavaran a gang: "imaza-u i teku.
qao kiljavaran a gang: "imaza-o i teko.
S.TRANSL: The crab said: “Stay here below.

S.FORM: vaik aken a łevavaw, a yaya tua kaludjeł a sema vavaw," ayain a qam.
vaik aken a ljevavaw, a yaya toa kalodjelj a sema vavaw," ayain a qam.
S.TRANSL: I’ll go up and pick the fruit up at the top,” he said to the ant-eater.

S.FORM: sa vaik timadju a łevavaw.
sa vaik timadjo a ljevavaw.
S.TRANSL: So he went up;

S.FORM: qau yayayain sa vułuvułuqan a pałeteku.
qao yayayain sa voljovoljoqan a paljeteko.
S.TRANSL: and he picked the fruit and threw it down below.

S.FORM: qau a qam i teku; łułułułuin, sa pilipiliqi tua namalum.
qao a qam i teko; ljoljoljoljoin, sa pilipiliqi toa namalom.
S.TRANSL: The ant-eater was down below, picking them up and choosing out the ripe ones.

S.FORM: azua namalum patalataladjen tua umaq nimadju.
azoa namalom patalataladjen toa omaq nimadjo.
S.TRANSL: He put the ripe ones in his house;

S.FORM: qau avan anga matjaq sakamaya a qinpu nua qam.
qao avan anga matjaq sakamaya a qinpo noa qam.
S.TRANSL: and it was just the unripe ones that he collected together.

S.FORM: qau łeteku anga azua gang.
qao ljeteko anga azoa gang.
S.TRANSL: The crab came down,

S.FORM: qau sa qenetji a qinpu nua qam.
qao sa qenetji a qinpo noa qam.
S.TRANSL: and had a look at what the ant-eater had collected.

S.FORM: mintu avan a matjaq sakamaya.
minto avan a matjaq sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: It was only the unripe ones.

S.FORM: qau "sema inu anga a namalum?" aya azua gang.
qao "sema ino anga a namalom?" aya azoa gang.
S.TRANSL: “Where have the ripe ones gone?” said the crab.

S.FORM: qau vaik azua gang.
qao vaik azoa gang.
S.TRANSL: The crab went off.

S.FORM: qau a qam izuanan itjua qapulu nua kaludjeł.
qao a qam izoanan itjoa qapolo noa kalodjelj.
S.TRANSL: The ant-eater was still at the foot of the tree.

S.FORM: qau lalapen nua gang.
qao lalapen noa gang.
S.TRANSL: The crab took (what was there).

S.FORM: mintu pinałetaladj anga tua umaq nua qam a namalum.
minto pinaljetaladj anga toa omaq noa qam a namalom.
S.TRANSL: The ripe ones had all been put in the ant-eater’s house.

S.FORM: qau vaiken a sema zua nua gang.
qao vaiken a sema zoa noa gang.
S.TRANSL: The crab went there.

S.FORM: mintu lialiaw a tsinpisan i taladj tua qinaman.
minto lialiaw a cinpisan i taladj toa qinaman.
S.TRANSL: And there were lots of fruit he had picked lying in the ant-eater’s den.

S.FORM: qau "aku maitazua ti tja qali?" aya timadju.
qao "ako maitazoa ti tja qali?" aya timadjo.
S.TRANSL: “Why is our friend like that?” he said.

S.FORM: qau kisan kuya timadju, sa vaik a tjumaq.
qao kisan koya timadjo, sa vaik a tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: He was annoyed, and went off home.

S.FORM: qau tsuatsuay anga metsevung tiamadju a maḍusa.
qao coacoay anga mecevong tiamadjo a madrosa.
S.TRANSL: After a long time the two of them met again.

S.FORM: qau małavar tiamadju: "nangaq a qemałup itjen," aya tiamadju.
qao maljavar tiamadjo: "nangaq a qemaljop itjen," aya tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: They said to one another: “Let’s go hunting.”

S.FORM: "tiakenay anan a temalaw.
"tiakenay anan a temalaw.
S.TRANSL: “I’ll first lie in wait,

S.FORM: tisunay anan a łemama tua łaviavia," aya a qam.
tisonay anan a ljemama toa ljaviavia," aya a qam.
S.TRANSL: while you set fire to the grass,” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: qau vaik a qam a sema taladj tua łaviavia.
qao vaik a qam a sema taladj toa ljaviavia.
S.TRANSL: The ant-eater went into the grass.

S.FORM: qau qemawqaw a gang: "inu anga sun?" ayain nua gang a qam.
qao qemawqaw a gang: "ino anga son?" ayain noa gang a qam.
S.TRANSL: The crab shouted: “Where are you?” he said to the ant-eater.

S.FORM: "imaza ken," aya a qam.
"imaza ken," aya a qam.
S.TRANSL: “Here I am,” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: "pai anga," ayain anan nua gang a qemawqaw.
"pai anga," ayain anan noa gang a qemawqaw.
S.TRANSL: “All right then,” shouted the crab again.

S.FORM: "mayanan," ayain nua qam.
"mayanan," ayain noa qam.
S.TRANSL: “Wait a bit,” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: manu semuasuad tua umaq azua qam.
mano semoasoad toa omaq azoa qam.
S.TRANSL: He scooped out a house;

S.FORM: qau maka suad azua qam tua umaq; łetaladj timadju.
qao maka soad azoa qam toa omaq; ljetaladj timadjo.
S.TRANSL: and when he had finished scooping it out he got inside.

S.FORM: qau qemawqaw tua gang: "pai anga.
qao qemawqaw toa gang: "pai anga.
S.TRANSL: Then he shouted to the crab: “All right now.

S.FORM: maka talaw anga ken," aya azua qam.
maka talaw anga ken," aya azoa qam.
S.TRANSL: I’m ready lying in wait,” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: qau łamain anga azua łaviavia nua gang.
qao ljamain anga azoa ljaviavia noa gang.
S.TRANSL: Then the crab set fire to the grass.

S.FORM: qau qawqawan nua gang: "inu anga sun?" ayain.
qao qawqawan noa gang: "ino anga son?" ayain.
S.TRANSL: And the crab shouted: “Where are you?”

S.FORM: "imaza ken," aya qam.
"imaza ken," aya qam.
S.TRANSL: “Here I am,” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: "inu anga sun?" ayain nua gang uta.
"ino anga son?" ayain noa gang ota.
S.TRANSL: “Where are you?” said the crab again.

S.FORM: "imaza ken," ayain nua qam uta.
"imaza ken," ayain noa qam ota.
S.TRANSL: “Here I am,” said the ant-eater again.

S.FORM: qau tsemalivat a sapui.
qao cemalivat a sapoi.
S.TRANSL: The fire passed.

S.FORM: "inu anga sun?" ayain uta nua gang.
"ino anga son?" ayain ota noa gang.
S.TRANSL: “Where are you?” said the crab again.

S.FORM: "imaza ken," aya a qam; sa łekatsauan tua umaq nimadju.
"imaza ken," aya a qam; sa ljekacaoan toa omaq nimadjo.
S.TRANSL: “Here I am,” said the ant-eater, and emerged from his home.

S.FORM: qau sa "tisunay anga a temalaw," ayain a gang.
qao sa "tisonay anga a temalaw," ayain a gang.
S.TRANSL: “Now it’s your turn to lie in wait,” the crab was told.

S.FORM: qau "muri a sema inu aken?" aya zua gang.
qao "mori a sema ino aken?" aya zoa gang.
S.TRANSL: “Where am I to go to?” said the crab.

S.FORM: tjumałan nua qam: "sazua-u itjua namaqurepung a łavia," ayain.
tjomaljan noa qam: "sazoa-o itjoa namaqorepong a ljavia," ayain.
S.TRANSL: The ant-eater told him: “Go in there in the tangled grass,” he said.

S.FORM: qau azua gang vaik a kipataluvtuv tua namaqurepung a łaviaviain.
qao azoa gang vaik a kipatalovtov toa namaqorepong a ljaviaviain.
S.TRANSL: So the crab went and curled up small in the place with tangled grass.

S.FORM: qau "pai anga," ayain nua qam.
qao "pai anga," ayain noa qam.
S.TRANSL: “All right then,” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: "pai anga," aya a gang.
"pai anga," aya a gang.
S.TRANSL: “All right,” said the crab.

S.FORM: qau łamain nua qam.
qao ljamain noa qam.
S.TRANSL: The ant-eater set fire (to the grass).

S.FORM: "inu anga sun?" ayain nua qam.
"ino anga son?" ayain noa qam.
S.TRANSL: “Where are you?” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: "imaza ken," aya a gang.
"imaza ken," aya a gang.
S.TRANSL: “Here I am,” said the crab.

S.FORM: qau tsemalivat a sapui.
qao cemalivat a sapoi.
S.TRANSL: The fire passed.

S.FORM: "inu anga sun?" ayain nua qam.
"ino anga son?" ayain noa qam.
S.TRANSL: “Where are you?” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: mintu nekanga.
minto nekanga.
S.TRANSL: No reply.

S.FORM: "inu anga sun?" ayain anan uta.
"ino anga son?" ayain anan ota.
S.TRANSL: “Where are you?” he said once again.

S.FORM: mintu nekanga.
minto nekanga.
S.TRANSL: No reply.

S.FORM: qau vaiken sa kiqenetji nua qam a sema zua.
qao vaiken sa kiqenetji noa qam a sema zoa.
S.TRANSL: The ant-eater went there to have a look.

S.FORM: mintu nakuḍesul anga namatsay anga.
minto nakodresol anga namacay anga.
S.TRANSL: And the crab was stiff and dead.

S.FORM: qau tseviqan a qalitsi.
qao ceviqan a qalici.
S.TRANSL: He sliced off some of the crab’s penis.

S.FORM: qau sa kisenay a papuvałut.
qao sa kisenay a papovaljot.
S.TRANSL: Then he chanted a spell and brought him back to life.

S.FORM: qau katsuin a qalitsi a tjumaq.
qao kacoin a qalici a tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: And he took the crab’s penis home.

S.FORM: qau kadjamadjaman anga.
qao kadjamadjaman anga.
S.TRANSL: Next morning,

S.FORM: qau sipakan anga a qalitsi nimadju nua qam.
qao sipakan anga a qalici nimadjo noa qam.
S.TRANSL: the crab was given some of his own penis to eat by the ant-eater.

S.FORM: qau "ha ha; kanen a qalitsi nimadju," aya a qam.
qao "ha ha; kanen a qalici nimadjo," aya a qam.
S.TRANSL: “Ha ha, he’s eating his own penis,” said the ant-eater.

S.FORM: qau kemłang azua gang tu qalitsi nimadju azua kinan.
qao kemljang azoa gang to qalici nimadjo azoa kinan.
S.TRANSL: Then the crab knew that it was his own penis that he had eaten.

S.FORM: "ii, pakanan aken tua niaken a qalitsi ni ku qali," aya, sa djiladjilay a gang.
"ii, pakanan aken toa niaken a qalici ni ko qali," aya, sa djiladjilay a gang.
S.TRANSL: “Ugh! My friend has given me my own penis to eat,” said the crab and spat.

S.FORM: łakua kudain, kinan anga nimadju a qalitsi.
ljakoa kodain, kinan anga nimadjo a qalici.
S.TRANSL: But there was nothing for it; he had eaten some of his own penis.

S.FORM: qau tsemikel anga a qalitsi nua gang.
qao cemikel anga a qalici noa gang.
S.TRANSL: (Later) the crab’s penis grew back again.
